reviews.text: Nonetheless, in its own fast and furious way, the film is cleverly constructed – a modern-day equivalent to one of those old matinee adventures in which Douglas Fairbanks would play swashbuckling pirates taking on the world.
reviews.author: Geoffrey Macnab

reviews.text: The Gray Man may feel 15 minutes too long, but there is still much to enjoy. Chris Evans is having a ball, Ryan Gosling cements his reputation as an action star in waiting, while Ana de Armas matches her co-stars in the arse kicking stakes.
reviews.author: Martin Carr

reviews.text: While the adrenaline-filled film boasts an all-star cast, top-notch camera-work and impressive stunt work, it lacks in character development and story giving us concepts we’ve seen over and over.
reviews.author: Nadya Martinez

reviews.text: For myself, star performances and expensive grand sets are two non-negotiable ingredients of a blockbuster. The Russo brothers’ newest film has both. (And maybe it’s just a two-ingredient genre film, but that’s perfectly fine with me).
reviews.author: Joshua Polanski

reviews.text: This movie will more than likely just be a random grey blank spot in your memory within a few days.
reviews.author: Shakyl Lambert

reviews.text: It's like somebody rabbit-punching your brain for the best part of two hours, and there's a certain enjoyability in that.
reviews.author: Mark Kermode

reviews.text: The Russo brothers’ supposed answer to the Bond franchise is a product of popcorn entertainment that is defined by giving the audience what they want and that’s just it.
reviews.author: Srivatsan S

reviews.text: Netflix’s The Gray Man is its Most Expensive and Emptiest Star Vehicle
reviews.author: Prabhjot Bains

reviews.text: In short, the movie looks like someone painted over each frame of the film with urine. The whole thing has this sickly yellow tint to it that's even more off-putting than the usual teal-and-orange colour grading of most big-budget blockbusters.
reviews.author: Ilan Preskovsky

reviews.text: Given Netflix’s expenditures and the star pedigree on screen, audiences deserve — and should expect — more.
reviews.author: Kevin Slane

reviews.text: If not an all-timer within a tried-and-tested genre, The Gray Man is a strong showcase for its leads, their screen presence and ability to carry the source material which can be overloading with exposition on occasion.
reviews.author: Christopher Connor

reviews.text: A flat out AWESOME! An action packed spy thrill ride that mixes the best of Winter Soldier, Fast/Furious, & John Wick. Ryan Gosling is that ACTION HERO…
reviews.author: Zach Pope

reviews.text: The Gray Man is just expensive, glamour-less, and unsharp.
reviews.author: Hector A. Gonzalez

reviews.text: If you've seen the trailer, you've basically seen the film; it is an underwhelming affair that sounds great on paper, but isn't executed well enough to be memorable.
reviews.author: Rebecca Johnson

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a wannabe John Wick lost in a tonally incohesive script. You’ve seen this movie before you even press play.
reviews.author: Tina Kakadelis

reviews.text: The Russo Brothers return with a star-studded action thriller in Netflix’s The Gray Man that’s great where the heart is concerned but nothing special overall.
reviews.author: Gissane Sophia

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a sad affair. As a fan of Ryan Gosling, as a fan of Ana De Armas, as a fan of Dhanush, as a fan of action cinema, this is sad.
reviews.author: Pramit Chatterjee

reviews.text:
We begin a 129 min journey jam-packed with quippy retorts, gratuitous violence and a hail of bullets that leap you chuckling and wiping tears of laughter from your eyes.

That being said, The Gray Man is entirely devoid of substance.
reviews.author: M.X. Katyayani

reviews.text: Unfortunately this did not flow for me. Gosling on paper seemed to be a very interesting character, but instead his character don't have real progression or likability. Then the action just wasn't up to par with what we've seen this amazing directors do
reviews.author: Samuel Leggett Jr.

reviews.text: Despite its fast-paced rhythm and the caliber of the talent in front and behind the camera, it ends up being an unimaginative and formulaic spy flick. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Rene Sanchez

reviews.text: What I also loved about this movie was the lack of an unneeded romantic subplot, and the fact that all the females in the cast weren’t brainless skirts simply there to fix the men or let them save their life.
reviews.author: Dan Buffa

reviews.text: If you can remember much about it 15 minutes after watching, you'll have a stronger impression than it made on me.
reviews.author: Steve Murray

reviews.text: An unapologetically pure action movie, and as such, tremendously entertaining.
reviews.author: Asia Frey

reviews.text: A movie devoted to fists, guns, and kicking as much as the “Fast and Furious” series showcases speeding cars.
reviews.author: Steve Crum

reviews.text: An A-grade budget trying to wallpaper over a B-grade script.
reviews.author: Matt Neal

reviews.text: In a world where entertainment can be reduced to an algorithm, gray denotes dispassionate neutrality instead of vari-hued complexity, cold industrialisation instead of creative sophistication. Which pretty much sums up Netflix's new pseudo-blockbuster.
reviews.author: Prahlad Srihari

reviews.text: Throw the Bourne, Bond, Mission: Impossible and Fast and Furious franchises into a blender... and — voilà — you might end up with a film like The Gray Man; you’ll forget it the moment you stop watching it.
reviews.author: Tom Shone

reviews.text: It has all the artistic value of watching a blank screen. Except a screen has a purpose.
reviews.author: William Bibbiani

reviews.text: Rather than take some narrative big swings, the story is content with keeping it conventional. But for those hungry for fast-paced grand-scaled action, the Russos have you covered.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a very bad, almost instantly forgettable film. What makes things worse in this case is that the filmmakers, the Russo brothers, do possess a degree of perception, talent and imagination.
reviews.author: David Walsh

reviews.text: This is an old-fashioned popcorn film, a violent feel-good fest of flash and sizzle and consuming it just makes you feel good.
reviews.author: Cris Kennedy

reviews.text: It can fairly be criticized as big, loud and derivative. But thanks to masterfully delivered one-liners from Ryan Gosling and top-shelf scenery chewing from Chris Evans it is, first and foremost, a fun film.
reviews.author: Mike Scott

reviews.text: It's a little vapid, but things blow up real good and Gosling is up for it.
reviews.author: Bob Grimm

reviews.text: The Gray Man strips the best qualities of everyone involved — there's a lack of personality to the filmmaking, and it's big for the sake of being big — leaving behind a tasteless pudding that reeks of a cashgrab.
reviews.author: Akhil Arora

reviews.text: What ensues is overly busy, dumb and riddled with cringingly glib dialogue.
reviews.author: Al Alexander

reviews.text: Here we go again with another substandard Netflix action film that seems to take pride in its display of stunning mediocrity.
reviews.author: Louisa Moore

reviews.text: For me this is like time past, but like the good kind.
reviews.author: Achara Kirk

reviews.text: I really enjoyed that… I thought it was a lot of fun.
reviews.author: Jaby Koay

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a worthy entertaining flick with enthralling action pieces, nice European cities and two handsome toughies that sustain their handsomeness ever after beating each other up across the globe.
reviews.author: Alejandro Turdó

reviews.text: Strong character leads mixed with enough action for the most jaded adrenalin junkie. Gosling is a smoldering assassin, aided and abetted by Ana de Armas. That duo dazzles.
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: A failure that exemplifies every bad trend in action filmmaking of the last 15 years, starting with a butt-ugly visual style in which almost everything is underlit, and action blowout sequences that have no spatial continuity.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: That Anthony and Joe Russo can take an ensemble like that and a $200-plus million budget and still deliver an uninspired, bland waste of talent is a crime that deserves the same level of investigation as Watergate.
reviews.author: Owen Gabbey

reviews.text: Frenetic and forgettable, this gun-riddled action-thriller continues to glorify active shooter emergencies....
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: How is Netflix still so bad at this?!
reviews.author: Scott Mendelson

reviews.text: The parts that work really work, even as the parts that don’t fall flat. However, if you’re a fan of large-scale blockbuster cinema, you’ll derive sufficient satisfaction from the good bits to make it worth a watch, though again - size isn't everything.
reviews.author: Allen Adams

reviews.text: The most glam dad-enjoys-while-folding-laundry movie ever.
reviews.author: Adam Kempenaar

reviews.text: It takes two long hours to repeat its world tour of shootouts, fights and chases in the service of the dizzying pyrotechnics of CIA agents who look like recycled copies of Jason Bourne. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: We’re threatened with a Netflix franchise here — Gray Man 2, 3, 4, and so on to infinity. This would be obvious even without the tiresome narrative set-up for sequels at the end.
reviews.author: Eileen Jones

reviews.text: All action, no heart.
reviews.author: Narayan Liu

reviews.text: Little emotion and no substance.  [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Hugo Hernández Valdivia

reviews.text: The nifty action beats, Gosling's snarky turn and Evans's villainous mustached douchebag keep things entertaining and elevate a weak, dull story. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: There can be pleasure in empty calories entertainment, especially in action films and reality television. However, the sin becomes apparent when one misuses many of our best actors.
reviews.author: Alan French

reviews.text: It is the type of film that believes that "more" is always "better": more action, more one-liners, more celebrities, and more visual effects. Unfortunately, that much excess results in a fun but shallow experience. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: ...an exceedingly (and often excessively) polished thriller that’s really only effective in fits and starts...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: An algorithm-infused product that barely has a beating heart.
reviews.author: Jordan Ruimy

reviews.text: After you’ve made movies about an intergalactic prophet throwing moons at superheroes, it’s hard to find something to top that.
reviews.author: Jon Winkler

reviews.text: A $200,000,000 snooze fest.
reviews.author: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh

reviews.text: Unfortunately, this movie’s by-the-numbers plot and dull action sequences make for exciting background noise but not a gripping big-screen bonanza.
reviews.author: Ani Bundel

reviews.text: As the company’s answer to the summer blockbuster, The Gray Man is indicative of the mediocrity that’s continued to seep into the streamer’s programming.
reviews.author: Miles Surrey

reviews.text: Forgive the movie for occasionally crossing the too-violent line, and a gripping good time is to be had here.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: Sodden with self-satisfaction and stupefyingly bad.
reviews.author: Simon Miraudo

reviews.text: Glaring in its lack of texture or flavour, this only really succeeds as a succession of mildly diverting bullet-riddled set pieces.
reviews.author: Dominic Corry

reviews.text: On the Netflix Original action scale, The Gray Man lands high when compared to their other “blockbuster” releases. The cg stinks and the script has the expected silliness, but there’s personality to spare and plenty of thrilling action beats to enjoy.
reviews.author: Rob Hunter

reviews.text: The movie may not have used it's budget or talent to it's full potential, but I still had a ton of fun with it.
reviews.author: Sean Chandler

reviews.text: It is all a bit much, but if this kind of movie is your thing (and you know if it is or not), and you don’t mind ridiculous video game violence with a hint of movie star charm, you may just have the most fun you’ll have all year.
reviews.author: Catherine Springer

reviews.text: draws liberally from the Bond and Bourne playbooks, but lacks the well-established wit and panache of the former and the grit and verité intensity of the latter
reviews.author: James Kendrick

reviews.text: The Gray Man is just passable enough to entertain for a couple hours, though you will likely forget everything but Chris Evans’ delightful douchebag performance.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: The Gray Man is so generic its makers could have forgone a title and opted instead for a universal product code.
reviews.author: Robert W. Butler

reviews.text: It is mere slick, workmanlike entertainment.
reviews.author: Whang Yee Ling

reviews.text: The Gray Man promises - and tries - to give us the whole world but falls short by many a mile.
reviews.author: Saibal Chatterjee

reviews.text: Beware, fans, your ears may implode. This thriller is a heavy load.
reviews.author: Betty Jo Tucker

reviews.text: The Gray Man could have been so much more, but that would have required so much less.
reviews.author: Asher Luberto

reviews.text: The fact that this is on Netflix denies the viewer of seeing this spectacle on the big screen which is a shame. However, it proves to be an advantage as being able to pause the film periodically is a plus.  You’ll need to catch your breath now and again.
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: Nothing beats the adrenaline rush of a suspenseful action thriller but watching The Gray Man makes me recall other movies that gave me that feeling, as there’s none of that to be found here.
reviews.author: Ruth Maramis

reviews.text: The Gray Man is not the worst film Netflix has put out by any means, but it is yet another example of the kind of bland and insipid anti-cinema that has become their trademark.
reviews.author: Petr Navovy

reviews.text: This is the kind of movie critics may be inclined to dismiss, but it tickles the tastebuds of viewers who like some bangs for their buck, an adrenalin blast and a few jokes.
reviews.author: Adam Sweeting

reviews.text: The film's misplaced, weak dialogue, combined with too many jump cuts for action sequences, make The Gray Man feel like a generic cross between the Marvel universe and John Wick. That is not to say the film is horrible, but it is not good.
reviews.author: DarkSkyLady

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a popcorn movie for the weekend, when in reality it doesn’t take any risks.  [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Alejandro Alemán

reviews.text: Mindless but well-acted and well-shot action pic.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: [A] likeable, muscular, high-octane thriller that you’ll remember for its chaos and carnage rather more than its generic serves-its-purpose storyline.
reviews.author: Paul Mount

reviews.text: All that effort and all that money should have paid for a better screenplay.
reviews.author: Robert Levin

reviews.text: Thrills on the level of an around-the-world DIEHARD, dirs Anthony & Joe Russo out-Bond multiple times better than the current Bond. Chris Evans plays the villain to the hilt, proving that a trash 'stache and white pants can work on certain types. Great!
reviews.author: Patrick McDonald

reviews.text: I'll give it a B- for its simple run and gun mindset and all the butt-kicking Ryan Gosling does.
reviews.author: Derek Sante

reviews.text: I feel comfortable assuring you that whenever there’s shooting, running, detonating, or general mayhem onscreen, you’ll like what you’re seeing.
reviews.author: Tim Brennan

reviews.text: A cliché on top of a cliché... A movie made out of recycled cardboard, made by Netflix's algorithm to entertain for two hours and be forgotten five minutes later. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juan Pablo Russo

reviews.text: He [Gosling] makes for a good sparring partner next to Chris Evans’ character. You can tell Evans is having an absolute blast as this reckless hotshot who dons some slicked back hair, a sharp mustache, and is the anti-Captain America.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a lot of flash with nothing to hold onto. Feeling that way about movies is not what I wanted. It left me feeling gloomy and gray.
reviews.author: Leo Brady

reviews.text: The Gray Man is the best example of the miserable state of contemporary action cinema.   [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ruben Peralta Rigaud

reviews.text: Killers with a conscience, flash drives and bosses are the real bad guys. Routine action is then not the counterbalance to the question why we are still wasting money making movies like this in 2022.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: The Gray Man is alright for an action movie on Netflix, but isn’t quite in the big leagues.
reviews.author: Natasha Alvar

reviews.text: Empty, obnoxious, upsetting.
reviews.author: Matt Pais

reviews.text: Somehow two directors who have defined blockbuster genre filmmaking recently can’t get a firm grip on this caper.
reviews.author: Alci Rengifo

reviews.text: …it’s hard going, instantly forgettable and impossible to start a franchise with…
reviews.author: Eddie Harrison

reviews.text: [A] bloated, brain-dead action movie...nothing more than a catena of big, noisy set-pieces held together by the flimsiest of plots, with an occasional bit of juvenile banter added to the otherwise pedestrian dialogue.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: Spectacular in a garishly stylized way somewhere on the spectrum between John Woo and Michael Bay.  Big, loud, dumb escapist spy thriller stuff with nothing to say but a lot to shoot at, chase and blow up.
reviews.author: Peter Canavese

reviews.text: As part of the weak story, there’s a flash drive involved, which contains a treasure trove of top secret information that shouldn’t get in the wrong hands. Yes, that old canard. Too much is done for laughs. Mark Greaney doesn’t write comic novels.
reviews.author: Michael Calleri

reviews.text: The whole movie is more and more and more: more explosions, more fireworks, more shooting, more bullets. The Russo’s didn’t care how preposterous this became. I think they got lost in their own mythology.
reviews.author: Roger Friedman

reviews.text: It's impossible not to be highly entertained by the super star cast clearly having the time of their lives, the explosive action scenes and the savvy directing skills of the Russo Brothers.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: Chris Evans, Ryan Gosling and Dhanush fight for your attention. The plot is clichéd, but the Russo brothers deliver a film packed with action, charismatic actors and beautiful locations.
reviews.author: Anupama Chopra

reviews.text: Another highly enjoyable spectacle from The Russo Brothers with some stellar action sequences and fun performances from Evans and Gosling.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: Love The Russos and I'm always down for a good spy adventure.  Yet, The Gray Man left me wanting just a tad bit more.  Having said that this all star cast led by Chris Evans and Ryan Gosling are everything and who doesn't love Aflre Woodard as a badass!
reviews.author: Carla Renata

reviews.text: A colorful, action-packed spy flick to please the Marvel loyalists but likely forgettable to many others. ... It’s enough globetrotting to fill James Bond’s passport, cover Indiana Jones’ flight map and make even Jason Bourne dizzy.
reviews.author: Jason Fraley

reviews.text: It is a big, noisy, explosive adrenaline rush — a live-action spin on that old "MAD" magazine comic, "Spy vs. Spy" — and about as deep.
reviews.author: Gary M. Kramer

reviews.text: I think they're looking for a series that could replace [James Bond], but in order for that to happen, people need to want to see to this one and the ones to come after, and I already know I don't want to see the next one.
reviews.author: Tim Cogshell

reviews.text: It's kind of like watching a movie that's a trailer for itself.
reviews.author: Peter Rainer

reviews.text: There’s some decent action set pieces and a formidable cast, but not enough to pop out of summertime filler.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: As with all Netflix productions with blockbuster dreams, this one is tailor made to be watched at home. You only need to lift your eyes from the second screen whenever you hear an explosion.  [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mario Alegre

reviews.text: The Gray Man doesn’t have much in the way of gray matter, and almost proudly has nothing to say about anything important.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: Directors Anthony and Joe Russo deliver an unrelenting fusillade of star-studded, big-budget action mayhem. Their adaptation of Mark Greaney's The Gray Man espionage thriller turns on a two-hour bullets and beatdowns spigot.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: If you love the MCU and loads of cartoonish CGI violence, then you’ll love “The Gray Man." If you’ve read the books, avoid the movie at all costs. If you haven't read the books—read them. It's a whole summer's worth of thoroughly engrossing page-turning.
reviews.author: Mark Jackson

reviews.text: For all the overkill, The Gray Man is big, loud fun. Mr. Gosling is hip to what's going on; Mr. Evans gets to gobble up the scenery. And even if the elements are hackneyed, they're not clumsy.
reviews.author: John Anderson

reviews.text: The film exists to set up sequels, to spend money on fancy location shoots, and to look glamorous and exciting; every harder edge has been sanded down to nothing.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: The Gray Man wallows in its obvious excesses because it doesn’t take itself remotely serious and neither does that stellar cast... which allows for almost every absurdity that unfurls on screen to possess a wink-wink-nudge-nudge kind of appeal.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: It as aggressively, soullessly stupid a chunk of high-density concrete as you’ll ever dial into.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: “The Gray Man” will easily fit the bill for action fans. It’s a big, loud, dumb spy-thriller that could become a franchise.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: I've watched far worse, but damn, The Gray Man is just a bland, ugly shell of an action movie.
reviews.author: Brent McKnight

reviews.text: Boundless, entertaining fun... And absolutely forgettable. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Randy Meeks

reviews.text: I suppose it's a world brimming with possibility, but The Gray Man doesn't offer us a compelling enough first chapter to have me groveling for more of the same.
reviews.author: Steven Prokopy

reviews.text: It's an action [film], one with fights, explosions, shootouts and a few gags. It isn't original, but it's fun. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: The Gray Man benefits from its talented ensemble cast, the Russos’ creative flair, and strong action work–it is just unfortunate that its frenetic pacing doesn’t complement the monotone premise, so it fails to revolutionize the spy thriller genre.
reviews.author: Katie Smith-Wong

reviews.text: Netflix broke the bank on this formula action epic fronted by Ryan Gosling and Chris Evans as assassins for hire. It’s good enough to rank as watchable. But even in these inflationary times, shouldn't 200 million bucks buy us more than good enough?
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: A decent, disposable action movie.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: Whilst it may not be particularly innovative, The Gray Man offers enough exciting action, two game leads, and plenty of spectacle over substance. As long as you don’t expect too much, you’ll have fun with this.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: [The] good news is, [Ryan Gosling] pulls off a convincing action-oriented role in The Gray Man.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: It feels like a mixtape, pulling bits from a bunch of much better, much more daring action movies, to create a medley that is mediocre at best.
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: Both (Ryan) Gosling and (Chris) Evans feel game for a much bolder movie, however the Russos play it safe in a movie that mistakes loudness for scale.
reviews.author: Tatsam Mukherjee

reviews.text: Directed with cardboard proficiency, there are some knockout action pieces: one sees the disintegration of a cargo plane; the other a chase involving a tram...They’ve got a marvelously kinetic, whiz-bang energy sadly missing from the rest of the film.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: Like a collage of other, better action pictures.
reviews.author: Allen Almachar

reviews.text: Combine that Avengers firepower with a charismatic all-star cast, and you'd think The Gray Man would be a must-see blockbuster. As it turns out though, it's more a can-barely-see blockbuster where the promising recipe ended up a mess on the floor.
reviews.author: Ian Sandwell

reviews.text: It’s involving and the action sequences are first-rate. but “The Gray Man” is a James Bond wannabe that requires a way too much suspension of disbelief.
reviews.author: Russ Simmons

reviews.text: Netflix’s latest actioner has a wonderful one played by Chris Evans. In this spy tale, he plays such a delicious bad guy that he manages to make up for many of the mistakes on display in this big-budget adventure.
reviews.author: Jeff York

reviews.text: My barista could have been cast as the lead of this action-thriller, and the film would be absolutely no different.
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: Another Netflix would-be blockbuster, another disappointment.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: It's cool to watch as a spectacle. As far as the story goes, there's nothing there. It's a very shallow film.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: Although it has a few loose ends to the plot, for the most part it’s one long adrenaline rush.
reviews.author: Daniel M. Kimmel

reviews.text: Nothing in "The Gray Man" is meant to be taken seriously; this is pure summer escapist fare where the quips rattle out with the same frequency as the machine gun blasts. Rat-a-tat, keep 'em coming.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a movie filled with cardboard character cutouts and Chris Evans doing everything he can to save this inexcusably dull thriller.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: The parts and the production values are in place, but without a well-devised thread or emotional soul binding them, that makes for a dull and drab affair.
reviews.author: Tom Meek

reviews.text: It's fair to say there's nothing particularly fresh about this premise, but getting to watch The Gos face off with The Cap? Well I could watch that all day.
reviews.author: Kate Rodger

reviews.text: There’s simply no life, which means it can’t be dumb fun.
reviews.author: Fletcher Powell

reviews.text: [The Gray Man] is the most generic piece of mail order crud imaginable given [the directors'] pedigree.
reviews.author: Matt Lynch

reviews.text: While Civil War or Endgame packed a lot of over-the-top spectacle but still managed the kind of well-rounded story from previous MCU phases, The Gray Man is simply adrenaline, action, chase scenes, hand-to-hand combat and not much glue in the middle.
reviews.author: Patricia Puentes

reviews.text: If anything, credit to the Russos, who have staked their place in film history as the most commercially successful directors to not have a single auteurist trait beyond corporate moviemaking fealty.
reviews.author: Ethan Vestby

reviews.text: "The Gray Man" barrels along, burning the millions of dollars earmarked for its cast, globetrotting ways and special effects. Is it good? Not really. But is it fun? Hell, yes.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: The Gray Man is much better than it should be when the plot is this generic, but it still leaves some room for improvement.
reviews.author: Maria Lattila

reviews.text: Nothing is particularly novel in The Gray Man ... and yet it all still works as a very entertaining action thriller with comedic elements throughout.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: It’s not the most original film you’ll see this year, but it benefits from two great stars who bring a lot of charisma to their roles
reviews.author: Victoria Luxford

reviews.text: [T]here's very little reason to care about anything happening on screen or anyone caught up in all of those happenings.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a big-budget, globe-trotting adventure that makes up in exotic locations and gunplay what it lacks in intrigue and interesting characters.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: "Gray" is the right word for such an empty, forgettable piece of would-be studio intellectual property.
reviews.author: Josh Bell

reviews.text: The movie feels increasingly tired. All that gunplay, all that traveling, all that sneering from Lloyd: Everything gets a bit . . . much.
reviews.author: Mark Feeney

reviews.text: A lot of really talented actors and cool visuals wasted. The Russo Bros clearly need Marvel, and some would argue Marvel clearly needs them. Let's get 'em back together before we have to watch any more of these bad non-Marvel Russo Bros directed movies...
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: Filmmakers Anthony and Joe Russo don't seem interested in nuance or understatement, but they do know how to take an audience on an engagingly outrageous rollercoaster ride.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: Even with Evans, Gosling, Ana De Armas and Billy Bob Thornton to deliver the script, it still barely raises a smile and very quickly becomes no more than a series of set-pieces.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: Star power is star power, and it’s enough to get a lot of this movie past its stylistic shortcomings.
reviews.author: Dan Scully

reviews.text: Note the moment during a strenuous tramway shootout when Six uses the reflection in a mirrored building to defeat a goon — it’s a clever detail in a film careening full speed ahead.
reviews.author: Amy Nicholson

reviews.text: Ridiculous and pointless, but The Gray Man was still entertaining. Work out the kinks and the end game, and I'll watch more of these films for Netflix.
reviews.author: Tania Lamb

reviews.text: The Gray Man is an obvious attempt at an action franchise for Netflix, especially since it’s based on a series that now features 11 books. If they can match the story with the action in future installments, they may have a bonafide hit on their hands.
reviews.author: Alex Bentley

reviews.text: It’s a film that gets no points for realism, but a lot of points for the turn-your-brain-off background noise that’s worth tuning in for every once in a while.
reviews.author: Jonathan Sim

reviews.text: Too preposterous to deliver Top Gun: Maverick-level fun, and not preposterous enough to deliver RRR-level fun.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: The Gray Man serves its purpose by providing a few fantastic action sequences and two exciting leads. Chris Evans plays it up beautifully. The overall experience is fun but extremely messy due to its scattered story and odd structure.
reviews.author: Austin Burke

reviews.text: It’s hard not to think of the title when contemplating the overall effect of a film that spares no expense to entertain, yet ends up feeling a little aimless, perplexingly bland, and -- what’s the word we’re looking for? Oh yes. Gray.
reviews.author: Jocelyn Noveck

reviews.text: The film is adrenalized but familiar, sporting a sarcastic sense of humor in an attempt to mitigate what's so threadbare about the premise and increasingly over-the-top fight sequences.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: Freed from the often-rigid constraints of the MCU, the Russos are at their most unrestrained, unleashing a film whose dynamism often overtakes the more laser-focused elements of this solid summertime action-thriller.
reviews.author: Douglas Davidson

reviews.text: Apathy is the most severe emotion the movie sparks.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: Though it's an enjoyable ride packed with movie star swagger, "The Gray Man" is a noticeably rocky road, and makes you wonder if the Russos can ever carry the same magic to the screen without the sparkle of Marvel's stable of heroes in their corner.
reviews.author: Matthew Jackson

reviews.text: The Gray Man is well-titled; this is an anonymous, by-the-numbers spy movie, with studiously bland features that make it almost impossible to pick out of a line-up.
reviews.author: Noah Berlatsky

reviews.text: Everything here feels so programmatically dull. It’s a silly piece of popcorn entertainment that too often forgets that this kind of venture needs to be fun.
reviews.author: Brian Tallerico

reviews.text: The action is, at times, hard to keep up with and lacks the crispness that would make it more engaging.
reviews.author: Nicole Ackman

reviews.text: It’s like a Fast & Furious movie, only with better dialogue and stronger actors delivering it.
reviews.author: Olly Richards

reviews.text: [An] unsubtle, clattering battle of the alpha males.
reviews.author: Anne Brodie

reviews.text: The Gray Man is mostly a collection of tired spy tropes, directed in a muddled and baffling way, that seemingly exists to set up what seems like will be a fairly unimaginative franchise.
reviews.author: Ross Bonaime

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a welcome reminder of Gosling’s lighter charms, ones he really should show off more often.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: The film knows its mission objectives and has the clinical, vicious skills required to meet them, but occasionally over-stretches itself by virtue of its attempts to be as big and bombastic as possible.
reviews.author: Tom Beasley

reviews.text: Evans and Gosling do what they can with a lackluster script, but its the over the top and ridiculous action that makes this a fun watch for those that just want to turn their brains off and watch explosions.
reviews.author: Tessa Smith

reviews.text: There is one piece that makes that non-stop action go down smoothly — Ryan Gosling.
reviews.author: M.N. Miller

reviews.text: Between these characters and the over-directed action, for a globetrotting assassin thriller, it’s not all that complex, but it satisfies more than most actual video game movies.
reviews.author: Aaron Neuwirth

reviews.text: 'The Gray Man' delivers on its promise of spectacular globetrotting action escapism, but there's a noticeable spark missing that could have elevated it above formula and into greatness.
reviews.author: Scott Campbell

reviews.text: The main takeaway from this one is that while the Russo brothers are excellent technicians, they’re not auteurs.
reviews.author: Travis Johnson

reviews.text: For all the explosions and violence and near-death escapes by our antihero, the film feels too detached from reality to make a deeper impact. There’s too much black and white, and not enough gray.
reviews.author: Todd Jorgenson

reviews.text: Ahead of its debut, it was touted that The Gray Man was the most expensive movie ever produced by Netflix. The film feels like more disposable entertainment from the streamer that is eager only to brag about how many eyeballs saw something.
reviews.author: Spencer Perry

reviews.text: Gosling has never been in the running for Bond but the deadpan La La Land star shines in this hugely entertaining adaptation of Mark Greaney's novel.
reviews.author: Andy Lea

reviews.text: Could've been "Face/Off." Instead it's just "Half/Off."
reviews.author: Nick Rogers

reviews.text: The Gray Man only needs to half-occupy the attention of Netflix subscribers, and it does not care whether they watch on a home theater system, or on the toilet. It goes through the motions of a spy thriller, rather than actually trying.
reviews.author: Alan Zilberman

reviews.text: It’s gripping and entertaining and it’s loud and bombastic. It’s also totally brainless, requiring very few IQ points to appreciate its entire proposition.
reviews.author: Wenlei Ma

reviews.text: For all the sensory overload – it’s a bit like being trapped inside a first-person shooter challenge being played by a 12-year-old gaming prodigy – The Gray Man is undeniably entertaining.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: The Gray Man would be the most insufferable big-budget release of 2022 if not for the charismatic star power of Ryan Gosling and Chris Evans.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: An insipid spy thriller that confuses big-budget spectacle for an engaging experience.
reviews.author: Matt Conway

reviews.text: An adrenaline-laced thriller that earns its place in the upper echelon of Netflix’s original films. If you loved The Old Guard or Extraction—which the Russos also helped shape—this is right up your alley.
reviews.author: Collier Jennings

reviews.text: Obviously intended as a franchise starter along the lines of Bond, Bourne, or Hunt, The Gray Man ... will likely end with a single, underwhelming entry, background fodder for game nights, post-prandial chilling, or boredom-related inertia.
reviews.author: Mel Valentin

reviews.text: That at least 50 shades of this feature have filled other films before can't be shaken, and yet that fact never blows up the movie... entertaining despite showing the easy dots it's connecting, and its seams.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: A strong cast and credible ending almost makes up for the screenwriting sins in a wall-to-wall actioner with, perhaps, some franchise possibilities.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: It’s not boring but it’s not exactly fun either.
reviews.author: Joshua Starnes

reviews.text: 'The Gray Man' makes amusing use of its all-star cast, but the action-thriller wastes the opportunity to do anything original.
reviews.author: André Hereford

reviews.text: "The Russos have all the skills.  The problem is, they use all the skills. If they did half of everything they can do, their non-Marvel movies would be doubly good… or if you want me to do the math… good, maybe really, really good."
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: The spy-versus-spy shenanigans plays like an excuse for the elaborate action sequences and insane stunt work, which produce a few genuine highlights but also yield gradually diminishing returns, especially down the home stretch.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: This is exactly the kind of diversion that’s such a treat when done well, and to see it done shabbily is just a massive disappointment.
reviews.author: Liz Shannon Miller

reviews.text: [A] gloriously brainless action spectacular...
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: The Gray Man is Bourne with a nod to Bond, part shoot-em-up video game, but also a kind of comedy -- this last ingredient crucial to its success.
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: Each CGI-filled set-piece is worse than the last.
reviews.author: Nick Johnston

reviews.text: Until very recently, Netflix had money to burn. And if you’d like to see $200-million of it go up in smoke, look no further than The Gray Man, the streaming service’s costliest production to date. Is it entertaining, you ask? That’s rich!
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: With an all-star cast, high-octane action scenes, and edge of your seat thrills, The Gray Man is an entertaining blockbuster that you can enjoy from the comfort of your sofa.
reviews.author: Lauren Bradshaw

reviews.text: Like a box of Milk Duds, it might not stay with you long, but it's easy enough to gobble down.
reviews.author: Piers Marchant

reviews.text: The Gray Man delivers one of the most satisfying action films of the year. Everyone in the all-star cast gets their time to shine with interesting and unique fighting sequences that showcase the intense choreography.
reviews.author: Matt Rodriguez

reviews.text: Part James Bond, Jason Bourne and John Wick and all adrenaline-fueled madness, Anthony and Joe Russo’s big-budgeted Netflix expenditure “The Gray Man” is a ludicrously fun exercise in explosions, shoot-outs, and wacky characters.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: A picture that tries desperately to be an over-the-top Mission: Impossible adventure only to end up in a no-man’s land of inconsequence.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: Saved only by its relentless pace, Gosling’s smarm, and Evans’s bluster, it is basically “Stupid John Wick.” Please note: John Wick is not a MENSA member.
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: I can’t help but think that Winter Soldier was a fluke.
reviews.author: Radheyan Simonpillai

reviews.text: There isn't a single original idea here, and that's fine!
reviews.author: Joshua Rivera

reviews.text: The Russos and their screenwriters, adapting Mark Greaney’s novel, have sufficient fun with all this for at least some of it to rub off on the audience.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: For all that bluster and the ever-appealing Gosling-brand reticence, one can’t help but pine for the relative complexity of the Fast & Furious sequence.
reviews.author: Tara Brady

reviews.text: While it eventually becomes watchable, it spends most of its runtime being visually and emotionally indecipherable.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: Joe and Anthony Russo’s use of drone cameras is genuinely fascinating.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: “The Gray Man” is non-stop assault on the senses as Marvel directors The Russo’s bring their over-produced style to Netflix.
reviews.author: Dustin Chase

reviews.text: It is easy to recommend this slick-but-not-too-slick globetrotting adventure, and it’s a solid bounce back for the Russos after last year’s “Cherry,” a disappointing based-on-a-true-story drama starring fellow MCU vet Tom Holland that landed on Apple TV+.
reviews.author: Mark Meszoros

reviews.text: The most enjoyable parts of "The Gray Man" are the two or three moments in which nothing blows up.
reviews.author: Kurt Loder

reviews.text: While this may be yet another potentially disposable action movie, it’s still worth seeing on the big screen at full volume if you can. The action is big and the stars give it their all, even if the dialogue leaves something to be desired.
reviews.author: Emily Zemler

reviews.text: The Gray Man seems to be exactly what it means to be, and in the moment, it's often fun. But there's something eerily vacant in its assembly.
reviews.author: Linda Holmes

reviews.text: For Gosling fans whose favorite movie was Drive, this feels like a slightly pumped up, dumbed-down version of that character, with significantly more to say about how he doesn’t actually have more to say.
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: Tedious and sluggish with punches and kicks and kills that barely satisfy, The Gray Man is a dead on arrival action thriller that squanders potential almost as often as Ryan Gosling chews gum.
reviews.author: Chris Sawin

reviews.text: There are a few high-octane and tense action sequences like the one on the Prague tram and a handful of stylishly choreographed fights, but The Gray Man's screenplay is shockingly elementary in dialogue and plot. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Batlle

reviews.text: The Gray Man cannot be called original... But it supplies an exceptionally well-made variation that outperforms many like it with an attractive cast, biting humor, and several riveting action sequences.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: Something perfectly serviceable to leave on in the background while noodling on your phone, and I mean that as a compliment.
reviews.author: Alison Willmore

reviews.text: Netflix’s charmless new action movie is a veritable tag cloud of keywords adapted into a lump of generic subscriber bait.
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: There is potential in every one of these action sequences, only for them to fall flat typically due to some combination of choppy editing, weightless stakes, a confused tone, and monotony
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: It's red-meat candy, a Bourne Identity for brains thoroughly trained in over-stimulation, and already long gone on summer holiday.
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: The Gray Man comes out blasting, that’s pretty much the extent of it.
reviews.author: Jamie Graham

reviews.text: The Gray Man is, essentially, the best dad action movie TNT will never broadcast.
reviews.author: Joey Magidson

reviews.text: The Gray Man wants to remind you of what an old-school dopamine dump these types of entertainments are, and it has what seems to be the necessary ingredients to do it. Which, to be honest, only makes you wish this was tighter, tauter, tougher, better.
reviews.author: David Fear

reviews.text: To put it in the reference-heavy parlance of The Gray Man: It's The Cringe Ultimatum, baby.
reviews.author: Dan Jackson

reviews.text: The Gray Man is the kind of action movie we’ve come to love from the Russos and a great time -- especially if you love Gosling and Evans just throwing one-liners at each other while getting stabbed, shot, punched, and thrown into cars.
reviews.author: Rachel Leishman

reviews.text: The experience of watching it is to be aware at every moment that what you are facing is a carefully calculated, wholly corporate product, entirely predictable and devoid of any authorship or originality.
reviews.author: David Sexton

reviews.text: The filmmakers aren't even content merely stealing plot points or interactions or motives from other works; they also borrow actors and practically the same characters they previously portrayed, to be inserted directly into this script.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: The Gray Man isn’t a bad movie, just one wilfully drained of substance or even dramatic tension.
reviews.author: Danny Leigh

reviews.text: In terms of delivering an entertaining blockbuster replica that will get subscribers to hit “Play”, The Gray Man gets the job done.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: An incredible cast and a simple enough premise completely undone by the Russo brothers' inconsistent visual language and overall shoddy filmmaking technique. In someone else's hands, with a less frenetic script, this could have been an easy layup.
reviews.author: Dominic Griffin

reviews.text: Not the return to cinema from Gosling we deserve.
reviews.author: Hannah Strong

reviews.text: They should have just called him “The Cliché Man.”
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: It is a thriller made by people who know what great thrillers can do, but without the ability to make one themselves.
reviews.author: Barry Hertz

reviews.text: An expensive (and expensive-looking) Netflix-produced action caper that sets the two marquee-topping actors against each other for instantly forgettable reasons.
reviews.author: Simon Abrams

reviews.text: Around halfway through a sustained shootout in Prague, the sheer thundering mindlessness of the whole enterprise becomes impossible to ignore.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: "The Gray Man" is the kind of needless action movie that usually gets released in late August... But along with its many other flaws, "The Gray Man" didn't even have the decency to wait a few weeks.
reviews.author: Cary Darling

reviews.text: A bad parody of a terrible Michael Bay movie.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: A Robert Ludlum-esque spy thriller that is more interested in dodging offending anyone’s politics than telling a coherent story, The Gray Man is perfectly mediocre entertainment because no single aspect is good enough to recommend.
reviews.author: Ryan Silberstein

reviews.text: It comes off as oddly limp and airless, one of Netflix’s $200m action films (à la Red Notice) that will be on their landing page today and instantly forgotten tomorrow.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: This is not a film weighed down by the need to be deep. But, dear Lloyd, it’s a hoot.
reviews.author: Charlotte O'Sullivan

reviews.text: A nearly nonstop two-hour action-packed ride that is part Bond, part Bourne, but really its own bag and a potential franchise-starter for Ryan Gosling.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: The result is a film that never seems to know what it's doing, or why. The irony is that it keeps trying to be The Bourne Identity, and yet it still ends up with an identity crisis.
reviews.author: Nicholas Barber

reviews.text: Tinkering with the spy-action wheel rather than reinventing it, this is a pacy, ruggedly entertaining romp, with a punchy pair of lead turns from Gosling and Evans.
reviews.author: John Nugent

reviews.text: While the movie itself may prove nearly as unmemorable as its hero ostensibly wants to be, it’s anything but inconspicuous.
reviews.author: John DeFore

reviews.text: Gosling is a great choice to play an implosive spy with a good heart and some long-suppressed family issues, and yet the character’s mottled contours are buried too deep to feel.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: Production budgets swell, stock prices go down, but Netflix subscribers are the big winners in this Bond-level summer blockbuster from the Russo brothers.
reviews.author: Peter Debruge

reviews.text: In spite of a pretty appalling script, the banter between Gosling and Evans is every bit as charming as expected.
reviews.author: Rachel Ho

reviews.text: It’s basically Netflix Winding Refn; it’s globe-trotting comic nihilism for the whole streaming-loving family.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: It’s really just two hours of Chris Evans in a bad mustache chasing Ryan Gosling around the world trying to kill him. You could do worse. Of course, you could also do better.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: The Russo brothers are aces at making superhero movies. They need more practice with superspies.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: There’s plenty of gonzo action but no heart and no real dramatic voltage.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: Wait and catch it on Netflix.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a noisy, flashy spectacle that piles clichés atop ludicrous plotting and sprinkles it all with half-funny quips.
reviews.author: Chris Barsanti

reviews.text: The Gray Man moves just as fast as the 1970s thrillers, too, with barely a moment to breathe.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: While the action can be taut and engrossing at times, and Chris Evans is terrific as a sociopath, “The Gray Man” ultimately feels like a movie we’ve seen a dozen times before.
reviews.author: Rodrigo Perez

reviews.text: A non-stop thrill ride full of jaw-dropping action, intense fight sequences, quippy dialogue and a dream cast highlighted by a deliciously evil Chris Evans as your new favorite villain.
reviews.author: Joey Morona

reviews.text: As long as the action remains at a smaller scale, it’s satisfying.
reviews.author: Matt Singer

reviews.text: It's entertaining, sure. Gosling is as buff as he’s ever been and all-in as an action star, and Chris Evans seems to enjoy playing psycho. But almost nothing happens in The Gray Man that doesn’t remind you of something better.
reviews.author: Jim Slotek

reviews.text: With relentless pacing and glamorous locales, there is a Bond-like quality to The Gray Man, although the Russos’ tendency to lean heavily on CGI detracts slightly.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: Evans's performance is, alas, the only notable thing in this preposterous, globe-trotting movie with so many cliché moments of barked dialogue it comes this close to sounding like a Saturday Night Live parody.
reviews.author: Jordan Hoffman

reviews.text: The Gray Man proves that the Russo brothers don’t need superpowers to turn massive budgets into mush.
reviews.author: Jacob Oller

reviews.text: An enjoyable romp slightly let down by a meandering screenplay.
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: An aggressively mediocre action flick.
reviews.author: Hoai-Tran Bui

reviews.text: With a sprawling, impressive ensemble, the filmmakers masterfully play to their actors’ strengths while gifting audiences with a thoroughly engrossing, entertaining (if not excessively so) summer thriller.
reviews.author: Courtney Howard

reviews.text: Silly but so much fun to watch. Ryan Gosling is a great action hero.
reviews.author: Chris Bumbray

reviews.text: The Gray Man is a spiritual throwback to 80s/90s action movies, with pulse-pounding fight scenes, delightfully cheesy dialogue & wickedly fun villain.
reviews.author: Molly Freeman

reviews.text: One of the better action movies of the year, twisting all of its Bourne and Bond influences into something quite different but equally exceptional.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: Netflix delivers with The Gray Man, a rip-roaring and star-powered spy romp that puts all the money on screen as Ryan Gosling and Chris Evans go head to head.
reviews.author: Richard Trenholm

reviews.text: Wall to wall, the Russos have unleashed what may stand as the best pure action movie of 2022.
reviews.author: Don Shanahan

reviews.text: I wandered into The Gray Man like a child toddles into a candy store with no adult supervision; it wasn’t healthy, things got a little sticky and very loud, but I had a good time. There’s just so much to see.
reviews.author: Sherin Nicole

reviews.text: As the tight polo-wearing, unstable lunatic with a chillingly calm demeanor when he feels like he's in control, you can pretty much tell Evans is having the time of his life playing a wickedly charming psychopath who answers to no one.
reviews.author: Matt Neglia

synopsis: When the CIA's most skilled mercenary--whose true identity is known to none--accidentally uncovers dark agency secrets, a psychopathic former colleague puts a bounty on his head, setting off a global manhunt by international assassins.
